body: Done
Is it OK to merge this PR?
I've improved compatibility with the previous implementation. Any objections against merging this into Wicket 8?
Thanks.
Go ahead!
@solomax: Thanks for the quick feedback. I adjusted the PR accordingly.

@svenmeier: This makes a lot of sense. I'm not sure however how much time I'll find the next weeks to work on this.

I suggest the following approach:

1. I'll look into this this week and try to rework the code as you suggested.
2. If It takes too much time and I can't finish it, I vote for merging a very simple version of this PR that only applies the changes required for making `wicket-bean-validation` work with BV 2.0. I'll remove the API changes I introduced in `BeanValidationConfiguration` and hard-code the list of built-in annotations that imply a not-null constraint. This way, we do not introduce any new methods that we would later remove if your solution is implemented.

WDYT?
That's a very good approach, thank you.
I pushed the simplified implementation without API changes in https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/246/commits/145e12e54c744b785f64ccf7acd5b8b0efda41e7.
@svenmeier I'll merge if you have no objections :)

I believe this can be closed
@theigl could you please close this PR?
We are currently using WicketTester for this, I'll try this later tonight and will give huge +1 :))
This does *not* solve (yet) one aspect of WICKET-6503: should components be allowed to be added to an AjaxRequestTarget *after* components have already been rendered ("ART is already frozen").

All test pass, there is a single change in FeedbackRenderTest only:

If IFeedbacks are *nested* (e.g. id1 -> id2 -> id3), *they* are prepared for render top-down (i.e. id1 then id2 then id3). This matches they way other components are rendered.

Previously the order was the other way around (i.e. id3 then id2 then id1), which was wrong IMHO.
Thank you, @aldaris !
Thank you, @andruhon !

A little bit of demo showing what I was trying to achieve:
https://github.com/andruhon/WicketDragAndDropFileAjaxUpload

Many thanks!

It seems you had to jump through a lot of hoops to make this work with Wicket's Ajax code - 
maybe we can change it to make this easier.
Why not drop the (old) iframe workaround and always use FormData for multipart requests?

I'll give it a try this afternoon.

@svenmeier I would agree that this legacy workaround is not a good thing for Wicket 8. IE 9 share is averagely less than 1% nowdays and keeps dropping. Those who need a legacy support of IE 7-9 can use Wicket 6. Thank You. Just let me know If I can help you with this.

@svenmeier I've tried a better approach without modifying the JS function Wicket.Ajax.ajax interface, it's always using multipart form data when possible and uses legacy approach as it used to work before (and works in IE9 as it used to work)

See it in the branch:
https://github.com/andruhon/wicket/tree/try-multipart

Also updated the demo to use this snapshot:
https://github.com/andruhon/WicketDragAndDropFileAjaxUpload/tree/try-multipart
tested in Chrome, FF, IE 11 and in emulated IE9-10

If it looks like decent approach I can update my PR.

Yes, this is what I came up with yesterday too.
We have to support file inputs in forms too, for that I changed serializeInput() to handle "file" types.

I'd like to drop support for the old iframe solution in submitMultipartForm(). I'll create an issue, let's see what other devs are thinking of this.
@svenmeier I'd say that submitMultipartForm could stay until the IE9 is closer to 0% in stats.

Just updated the demo which proves that Drag and Drop file upload now works with this branch.
https://github.com/andruhon/WicketDragAndDropFileAjaxUpload
tested in IE10-11, Chrome and FF
Much better! Now only the relevant things are available and if the user wants to go for logback he just can add it, but doesn't need to remove not used xmls if logback isn't used. üëç
I'm pretty sure that target should also be passed into AjaxFileDropBehavior#onError, to make it possible for us to react somehow (show some feedback)

Hi,

is this PR reflection a subset of changes of: https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/256?

If yes we might consider to close this one and continue it in only one PR.

Thanks a lot for your PR @andruhon üëç

Thanks a lot @svenmeier!
All tests are green now :)

Shall we merge?
Nope, not yet please. I have a new idea I want to try out.
Sure :) no rush, just would like to check if everyone happy with this PR :)

Many thanks Maxim for your work on this!

But with #258 we have a much simpler solution now, that should please those that are sceptical about the changes presented here.

If no one objects, I'll close this pull request.
@solomax I'm sorry for all the hard work you put into fixing the tests, but #258 is much better than this initial solution. Closing.
NP, I'll check the tests again  :)
There aren't many test to check - the new pull request does not change the current Ajax implementation at all :p. IMHO that's a huge advantage.
Wicket Ajax has preconditions (`pre`) for canceling.

@martin-g I think it's a bit different: as far as I understand preconditions checked before the `jQuery.ajax` is called, but what I say happens after but before jQuery did actually start this request. I think I should create a separate issue with a little demo for this.

@andruhon I understand what you say. I just explain how it works now.
So preconditions are too soon for your use case ?

I have `AjaxEventBehavior("click")` added to the component, and got exception in browser console:
```
Cannot bind a listener for event "click" on element "toggle58" because the element is not in the DOM
```

The issue in `org.apache.wicket.markup.head.ResourceAggregator.renderSeparateEventScripts()` method
`domReadyItems` are being wrapped into `NativeOnDomContentLoadedHeaderItem`, but `org.apache.wicket.markup.head.filter.JavaScriptDeferHeaderResponse.NativeOnDomContentLoadedHeaderItem.render(Response)` is not being called, not sure why :(
Seems to work in wicket-examples. What's the difference?

Will try to create quickstart
Might take some time .....

@svenmeier 
here is incomplete investigation: I can see same errors using latest 8.0.0-SNAPSHOT from master branch :(
I have checked commit-by-commit and this behavior caused by this https://github.com/apache/wicket/commit/c27a57b31a0e519ef15dfe08b425d85f9a24f685 commit
I'll try to continue investigating using diffs tomorrow
Will appreciate any help here

Hm, that would be an error on my other building site :P

I have no clue what might causing this atm.

Hello @svenmeier 
Finally I was able to create quick-start https://github.com/solomax/repeater-with-events, 
The issue is reproducible using latest wicket-core from master branch
The issue is NOT reproducible in case this https://github.com/solomax/repeater-with-events/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/solomax/MainPanel.java#L34 line is commented out `setAuto(true);`

Hope you can understand what "magic" was broken :)))
Anything related to setAuto() must be magic.
Actually the problem is just your MainPanel that pretends to be auto, but actually is not: its beforeRender() and that of the contained DataView is call twice. I'll fix this.

This was an issue with WICKET_6503, which is now fixed on master. Thanks Maxim!

So back to deferred JavaScript :)

Thanks @svenmeier , `Auto mode` seems to work :)
I have updated https://github.com/solomax/repeater-with-events with case that fails in deferred mode ....
I'll try to check this from my side
It seems I should use `git rebase` while merging ....

Thanks @svenmeier, my bad, I should investigate deeper.

+1 for merging this PR, everything works as expected :)))

>should we just always include them

Good question. IMHO it would make sense to always fire these 'new' events.

The code looks good to me
Our main application also seems to work as expected with this version

+1
Merged into master
This should be backported to 7.x/6.x, no ?
It has already been backported. The patch applied mostly cleanly on 7.x and 6.x.
I created an issue in JIRA with beforeSend issue mentioned above https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-6532

Thank you very much for the review.

I fixed to check if session exists and changed WebSession to Session.

Alrighty, preliminary check with that in place:
It breaks 214 tests, so it's gonna take a bit to update all of the tests.
I've pushed the state so you can take a look as I'm working on updating the tests, so I wouldn't recommend accepting the PR just yet.

Should I take the opportunity to update some of the tests, such as `AttributeModifierComponentTest`?
It seems to use an old way of verifying rendered content.
I could migrate it over to the, seemingly, standardised `_expected.html` variant.

Is merged with commit https://github.com/apache/wicket/commit/3be55cf5a24982cfca400225aabb6c4296859a7d

With the addition of these new mobile browsers user agent strings the code becomes more complex.
Maybe we should think in direction how to make use of external libraries to do this checks, e.g. https://github.com/pieroxy/java-user-agent-detection or https://github.com/HaraldWalker/user-agent-utils, https://github.com/browscap/browscap/wiki/Using-Browscap#java
And/or maybe browser list and supported patterns can be cleaned up to support more recent versions only?
drop this "feature" completely - it just wont work reliable anyway
Thanks :+1:

Hi,

we are using a CORS enum for media tags already, maybe this is a good moment to use the provided class in there, too.

@svenmeier I just told that if there are more places I remember your suggestion üòÑ 

WDYT?
@klopfdreh indeed, now is the time to reconsider the former decision  :+1:

For a usage example and test I made
[CORS.zip](https://github.com/apache/wicket/files/1874596/CORS.zip), a mofified quickstart showing a bootstrap 4 page with bootstrap css and jquery, popper and bootstrap js with CORS.
Glad that you find it useful.....

I just tested a bit around and I would suggest the following changes:

* Drop the support for minor version in exchange for a full version String (11.0, 3.5.8, 4.0b4a)
* Change the implementation to yauaa - I also played around a bit and found some not correctly resolved version numbers (the browsers are all detected correctly) https://github.com/nielsbasjes/yauaa/issues/75
* Change the UserAgent enum to not handle excludes, but only browser names

If the issue is fixed I can provide a PR.

Guys I get it, there are many good solutions to choose from, but why should we make Wicket dependent on anyone of them?

https://github.com/nielsbasjes/yauaa looks good, but do users really need assistance for this?

`UserAgent  userAgent = analyzer.parse(new WebClientInfo(requestCycle).getUserAgent());`
In my opinion and because of such a big pool of browsers I would say yes.

@tremel thanks for your usage example.

It seems to me we're mixing at least three topics in this pull request:
- JavaScriptReferenceHeaderItem needs integrity and and crossOrigin ... fine
- JavaScriptUtils#writeJavaScriptUrl() is getting to many parameters, maybe an attribute map can help here?
- references cannot alter the attributes of their headerItem (besides the url of course): defer, async, charset and now integrity and crossOrigin

IMHO we should solve the last issue separately and uniformly, i.e. not IntegrityAttributed but maybe a broader interface for all attributes or just a callback that allows the reference to alter the headerItem.
For now you could use an IHeaderResponseDecorator to set the attributes.
@svenmeier maybe a bit off topic but what about version itself? jQuery 2 vs 3? - AFAIK wicket 8 should work with jQuery 3.3.1 out of the box?
@kbachl all jQuery 3.x should work fine. If you think Wicket should switch to v3 as default, you an open anothe issue. For me v2 is fine though.
@svenmeier thx for the info - I originally meant we should mention this maybe in the docs and also provide  the library of jquery 3.3.1 with wicket 8 together?
See my suggestion over here: https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/275

Following changes have been made:

* The init() method has been changed into gatherExtendedInfo() which is only be executed if org.apache.wicket.settings.RequestCycleSettings.setGatherExtendedBrowserInfo(boolean) is set to true
* MetaDataKey has been used to initialize YAUAA
* All browser specific methods have been moved into detectBrowserProperties
* gatherExtendedInfo / detectBrowserProperties are protected / public so that the user may override them

The reason why I moved gatherExtendedInfo() from out of the constructor is, that YAUAA takes a long time for initialization and if not required might be a bit to much overhead.

Yeah, that's a better idea.
Deprecated `ArrayListStack`, and deleted `HandleArrayListStack` (Package-private unused sub-class).

Cool!

Please just add Javadoc about the `tparam`s of IMetadataContext!
LGTM!
Added some javadoc with some barebones explanation.
Hi @solomax - thanks a lot for the review. Because I am not able to work on it currently I am going to grant you access to my repo for further commits. Is this ok for you?
OK :) I'll merge my changes
I send you an invitation to the repo in which the branch of the PR is located. just push to it and merge if you are done. I think we are on a good way with this integration.

I just realised I should probably do `IMetadataContext<B, R extends IMetadataContext<B, R>>`

Thoughts?
I went ahead and changed it.
What about merging this? Or do we proceed with this PR after the release @bitstorm ?
Close this one in favour of the mentioned one? (https://github.com/apache/wicket/pull/275)
OK, let's close this one :)

My concerns still hold :(

Most importantly: with that single UserAgentAnalyzer instance you've introduced a bottleneck for all concurrent request that need to gatherExtendedInfo().

To create UserAgentAnalyzer takes rather a long time. Maybe we are able to find a way to resolve the bottleneck, but my concerns to implement the browser detection in such a bad way like it was before also still hold.

Also when I see the benchmarks I would consider to just inform about the bottleneck and keep it that way, or to turn gatherExtendedInfo() off if 0.011ms are to much.
